Parameters: the specific data source we want to display data for
setDataSource(com.google.android.gms.fit.Description: Sets the data source to display data for, if a specific data source is desired. Otherwise, the viewer can choose any data source or use the default one.

Parameters: the package name for the application we want to link to
setPreferredApplication(java.lang.String.Description: Sets a preferred application to use for this intent. If the given app is installed and able to handle this intent, an explicit intent will be returned. This can be used in combination with @B_com#google#android#gms#fitness#data#DataSource#getAppPackageName_E@ to link back to the original application which inserted the data being displayed.

Parameters: start time, inclusive, in milliseconds since epoch
end time, exclusive, in milliseconds since epoch
setTimeInterval(long, long).Description: Sets the time interval to display data for. Every intent requires a valid time interval.
setTimeInterval(long, long).FullName: public ViewDataIntentBuilder setTimeInterval (long startTimeMillis, long endTimeMillis)

Throws: if not enough data has been passed into the Builder to build a valid intent.
build().Description: Returns the built intent, which can be used with @B_android#content#Context#startActivity_E@ to launch the desired Fitness activity.

ClassDesc: Builder of intents to view data stored in Google Fit, for a particular @B_com#google#android#gms#fitness#data#DataSource_E@. This intent can be used when the application wants to display a more detailed view of a particular data type. Apps that can handle that data type (such as the app that inserted the data) can register for the intent. If desired, @B_com#google#android#gms#fitness#ViewDataIntentBuilder#setPreferredApplication_E@ can be called to set a specific application to handle the intent, if the application is installed on the device. This will often be the application defined in @B_com#google#android#gms#fitness#data#DataSource#getAppPackageName_E@. The data view intent has the following attributes: @B_com#google#android#gms#fitness#FitnessIntents#ACTION_VIEW_E@ @B_com#google#android#gms#fitness#FitnessIntents#MIME_TYPE_DATA_TYPE_PREFIX_E@ followed by the data type name. For example vnd.google.fitness.data_type/com.google.step_count.cumulative. @B_com#google#android#gms#fitness#FitnessIntents_E@. An application that would like to handle data view intents should create an activity and add an intent filter to its manifest file. Here's an example activity that can display heart rate data:
